body: THE surge of hotel development in New York City over the last two years is starting to appear a bit ''frothy'' to some industry watchers. ''We had someone here make a list of every hotel development project announced in the five boroughs, and she stopped counting at about 60 and probably missed another 20 or so,'' said Thomas McConnell, a senior
title: SQUARE FEET | CHECKING IN; Hotels Discover The Brooklyn Vibe

body: Ten, 9, 8, 7, 6 nights before Christmas and Santa is in full effect outside the Nextel store on the Fulton Street Mall. He cranks up the skipping soca rhythm on the backing tape and kicks it to the crowds pouring off the buses and trudging with bulging shopping bags down Brooklyn's bustlingest outdoor retail strip. ''Siii-lent night, hooo-ly
title: Step Right Up! Brooklyn Mall Is Oasis and Anomaly

author: Art by Marvin Franklin: nytimes.com/thecity More Dispatches: nytimes.com/cityroom
body: MOST mornings over the last decade, after a long, dark night underground working on the subway tracks, Marvin Franklin would ride the F train to the end of the line and make his way to his home in St. Albans, Queens. He would then regroup, turn around and ride back into Manhattan for three hours of art classes. Usually he was carrying a sketch pad
title: DISPATCHES; Rich Legacy Of an Artist Of the Rails

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites HOLIDAY PARTIES If it weren't for the cabs, New York on Christmas Eve would feel as underpopulated as it does in ''I Am Legend.'' title: Spare Times

body: ''You just have to be careful,'' said Jeffrey Watler, wearing a winter coat over the collared shirt required by his employer, a messenger service. Knapsack on his back, he threaded his way through pedestrians, bike messengers and dogs on the way to his next pickup near Grand Central Terminal. For Mr. Watler, 25, who walks with an impaired gait and
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Facing Treacherous Streets With Limited Mobility

body: Looking Ahead AMY RUTH'S The Harlem soul food restaurant will open a branch in the landmark Gage & Tollner space in downtown Brooklyn in February. Gage & Tollner closed in 2004, and the space had most recently been a T.G.I. Friday's: 372 Fulton Street, (Jay Street), Brooklyn. LIA ON 69TH STREET A Viennese-style coffee house and wine bar is to open
title: Off the Menu

body: A man who robbed a bank in Brooklyn on Monday morning may have not only returned to the scene of the crime, but he may also have robbed it again. ''Same bank, same day -- that's not a common occurrence,'' said Detective Kevin Czartoryski of the New York Police Department. ''We suspect that we're going after the same guy here.'' The first robbery at
title: Bank Robbed Twice, Maybe by Same Man

body: AS a teenager growing up in Flatbush, Allan Pepper used to set aside his schoolbooks every evening and tune in to the radio station WINS for the alternative education offered by the legendary D.J. title: URBAN TACTICS; A Fabled Club Seeks an Encore in Brooklyn

author: Rob Walker writes the Consumed column for the magazine. His book, ''Buying In: The Secret Dialogue Between What We Buy and Who We Are,'' will be published by Random House next June.
body: The declaration from something called the Handmade Consortium materialized on a Web site called buyhandmade.org in late October. title: Handmade 2.0

body: The Nets, who had hoped to move into a new arena near downtown Brooklyn in time for the 2009-10 season, have acknowledged that construction will not be finished until sometime in 2010. title: Wait Until 2010, Nets Say of New Brooklyn Arena

title: In Help for the Homeless, Hope for a Recovering Addict

body: At first, Gov. Eliot Spitzer told a packed room of Assembly Democrats yesterday, his wife didn't like him much either. After meeting his bride-to-be, the Southern-bred Silda Wall, at Harvard Law School in the 1980s, he asked her out, and she said no. But he was persistent, Mr. Spitzer said, and she finally agreed. Now, they are happily married. All
title: Spitzer, Hat in Hand, Asks Fellow Democrats in the Assembly for a Second Chance

body: Art Robin Pogrebin The Ashcan School is most closely associated with realistic depictions of hardscrabble urban life in the 1930s. But the artists identified with the movement also portrayed scenes of enjoyment at cafes, theaters, beaches and bars. On Wednesday the New-York Historical Society will present a sampling of these images. The exhibition,
title: THE WEEK AHEAD | Nov. 25--Dec. 1

body: Throughout the contentious prehistory of the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, just about every fact and figure about the planned development has been passionately debated, from the height of its tallest building, to the number of apartments that will be affordable to those of modest means, to the amount of taxpayer financing it will require.
title: A Brooklyn Arena and the Street: What's the Right Distance?

body: Shanta Williams worries that one day she will wake up and have one child, not two. There was the morning she noticed that her baby, Justin, had an unnatural pallor. He had stopped breathing in his sleep. The ambulance arrived, and emergency workers managed to revive him. Other times his tiny body would shake and shake and shake, like a vibrating
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; An Illness Brings Hardship; a Diagnosis, Relief

title: Martin D. Raab, 75, an Architect for the City

title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK | ATLANTIC AVE., BROOKLYN; An Exotic Oasis in Brooklyn

body: Of the many criticisms leveled against the planned Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, two of the major ones are that it would worsen traffic in an already congested area and that its 18,000-seat basketball arena might provide a tempting target for terrorists. So when the city of Newark decided last month, just before the opening of its new
title: Security Study Urged for Atlantic Yards

body: TRAFFIC, apparently, hits a nerve. In the wake of Mayor Bloomberg's proposal to calm Manhattan traffic through a plan called congestion pricing, the City section asked its readers to offer their own solutions for easing the borough's traffic woes. More than a hundred responded, proposing ideas ranging from the wonky to the off-the-wall. Ban cabs.
title: Grrridlock

body: IF John Berglund was going to take a job in New York, he and his family most certainly were going to live in the center of the city. They had already lived in the suburbs and the country. City living was ''part of the adventure for us at this time of our life,'' said Mr. Berglund, 55, the Salvation Army's director of emergency disaster services for
title: THE HUNT; Ready for City Life

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites TAKEOVER The powers that be at the Brooklyn Academy of Music are very trusting. title: Spare Times

author: E-mail: haberman@nytimes.com
body: Five years had passed since I last took up the challenge of the race now formally known as the ING New York City Marathon. It was gratifying to see that age had dulled neither the competitive spirit nor the stamina. Quite the opposite. This was my fifth marathon in the last 13 autumns, and I finished with my best time ever: 2 hours and 28 minutes.
title: NYC: Taking the Measure of the City's Streets: Some Do It by Foot, Others by Car

body: To the Editor: Re ''Mr. Mayor, for Your Consideration'' (editorial, Oct. 22), which suggests several ways to bring order to our streets: Making New York less congested and more pedestrian-friendly will increase quality of life, improve our physical and mental well-being, and begin to address the health of the planet. While I understand the calls
title: LETTERS; Can Anybody Tame New York's Mean Streets?

body: An emotionally disturbed man attacked a transit officer guarding Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday as he waited for a Lexington Avenue train in Lower Manhattan, the authorities said. Mr. Bloomberg was not harmed in the incident, which occurred at about 1:20 p.m. as he was walking with a group of aides and plainclothes police officers along the
title: Officer Guarding Bloomberg Is Attacked; Mayor Is Unhurt

body: A one-day strike called by the New York Taxi Workers Alliance had little effect on the daily commute yesterday, according to city officials, commuters and drivers. At a news conference yesterday afternoon in Downtown Brooklyn, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the strike, which began at 5 a.m. and was to end today at 5 a.m., had ''no appreciable
title: City Cabdrivers Strike Again, But Protest Gets Little Notice

body: No one could have predicted a decade or so ago that the Devils would be the first team in the New York-New Jersey market to have a new arena or stadium. title: SPORTS BUSINESS; Devils Win The Race To Be First

body: THE Brooklyn real estate market has turned into a bundle of contradictions in recent months. While prices in neighborhoods like Park Slope and Brooklyn Heights soared this summer, so did the number of foreclosures in neighborhoods like Bushwick and Bedford-Stuyvesant. Sorting through these contradictions, buyers are starting to find bargains in a
title: Brooklyn: A Bargain Hunter's Guide

body: LAST month the City of New York gave Duffield Street in downtown Brooklyn an alternate name: Abolitionist Place. It's an acknowledgment that long before Brooklyn was veined with subway lines, it was a hub of the Underground Railroad: the network of sympathizers and safe houses throughout the North that helped as many as 100,000 slaves flee the
title: WEEKEND EXPLORER; On the Trail Of Brooklyn's Underground Railroad

Appearing before the United States Appeals Court for the Second Circuit, a lawyer for the
title: U.S. Court Hears Opponents of Atlantic Yards Argue for Reinstating Suit

title: Dining Briefs

body: Planners have long been keen to use parks to keep the city at bay, to provide a retreat from urban bustle. This perspective has led to some undeniably great places, such as Central Park and Prospect Park, but to Mr. Kent's mind, it has also limited an understanding of the potential of public spaces. Case in point: the parks north of Brooklyn
title: Brooklyn Borough Hall

body: Fifty years later, historical revisionists have all but beatified Walter O'Malley for absconding to Los Angeles with the Brooklyn Dodgers after the 1957 season. title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; Time Doesn't Relieve the Pain, or Change the Facts

We will miss his wit, his intelligence, and his
title: Paid Notice: Deaths SCHULTZ, HARVEY

body: The new stadium the Jets and the Giants are scheduled to occupy in 2010 will be distinguished by an outer skin of aluminum louvers and by interior lighting that will switch colors depending on which team is playing at home. The changing colors -- green for the Jets, blue for the Giants -- reflect each team's desire to individualize the look of the
title: Kaleidoscope of Colors Coming to New Stadium

body: On many mornings, as commuters pack themselves into subway trains and drivers squeeze onto the streets, Janette Sadik-Khan, the commissioner of the Department of Transportation, rides her bicycle to work. title: To Ease a City's Traffic, Shifting From 4 Wheels to 2

title: Fire Commissioner, No Stranger to Criticism, May Face Greatest Challenge in Fatal Blaze

body: Although a few companies in other industries have begun moving in, office real estate in Jersey City is still very much an annex of Wall Street. title: Jersey City Landlords Prosper in New York's Shadow

title: Subway Supervisor Is Demoted For His Role in Fatal Acccident

title: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Hue and Cry

body: Geraldine Young was a former schoolteacher, 58 and single, who one day said God told her to take in homeless men and let them stay in the five bedrooms above her own. title: Samaritan's Death Raises Questions About Her Choices

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

body: The city that never sleeps is also the city that never stops rebuilding. title: SQUARE FEET; Checking Out Real Estate in New York to Make a Map, Not a Deal (Really)

body: VISITING the big city can leave you parched, especially in summer. It's easy to develop a more-than-one-beer thirst as you gamely tramp from museum to museum, from landmark to landmark. title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK: BARGAIN BARS; For Beer Tastes, on Beer Budgets

''I thought they were going to complain about the noise,'' Ms.
title: Spare Times

body: The deaths of two subway workers in April resulted primarily from flawed safety procedures and a lax ''organizational culture'' in which track workers and supervisors flouted basic safety rules and failed to alert operators of oncoming trains to the presence of workers on the tracks, according to reports released yesterday by New York City Transit.
title: Safety Violations Cited for Deaths In Subway Work

body: AROUND TOWN HARLEM WEEK Now in its 33rd year, the month of festivities known as Harlem Week continues on Sunday with a full day of events. ''A Great Day in Harlem'' begins at noon in Ulysses S. Grant National Memorial Park, with performances from Broadway and Off Broadway plays; an excerpt from ''Lady Sings the Blues,'' featuring blues and jazz
title: Spare Times

body: AROUND TOWN 'CARIBBEAN GARDENS: JOURNEY TO PARADISE' For those stuck in the sweltering heat of the city, the New York Botanical Garden is offering a sliver of the tropical experience this summer with ''Caribbean Gardens: Journey to Paradise.'' Housed in the main glass conservatory, and the 11 glass houses attached to it, this show has an array of
title: Spare Times

author: E-mail: bigdeal@nytimes.com
body: WHEN Edgar Bronfman Jr. signed a contract to sell his town house on 15 East 64th Street -- for $51 million, brokers say -- the price might not have set a record, but it might be the priciest ''for sale by owner'' transaction ever. Homes offered for sale by owner, known as FSBOs (pronounced FIZZ-bos) are sold without a listing broker, and usually
title: Big Deal; A Record FSBO?

body: WHERE do you live? For New Yorkers, the answer to that question can take any number of forms, general, specific or existential. Uptown, downtown, Brooklyn or Queens. The West Village, the Lower East Side, 102nd and Riverside. On the knife edge of despair. In a state of perpetual anxiety. For me, the nonexistential answer is painfully complicated.
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; The Man Without a Country

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites BASTILLE DAY Tomorrow is Bastille Day, when French nationals and Francophiles all the world over commemorate the storming of the Bastille in 1789. title: Spare Times

body: SOMETIME in the hours after I found out my car had been towed, after I broke into a sweat on a cool night on a lush corner of Park Slope, yanked the earphones out of my ears, stood in dumb silence for a while and then trudged home, it occurred to me that perhaps I had become a part of something larger than myself. title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Rite of Passage

body: It may seem surprising, but when it comes to land for residential or commercial development, gasoline stations clean up nicely, real estate brokers say. As a result, they are steadily disappearing from New York City's five boroughs. From September 2003 to February of this year, the city lost about 9 percent of its gas stations, declining from 1,837
title: SQUARE FEET; Shops and Condos Crowding Out Gas Stations

body: After years of delays, and some notable failures, the city's 911 call system is getting a $1.5 billion overhaul that will include a backup center and will, for the first time, consolidate operators and dispatchers from all of the emergency services in two centers, according to aides to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. Under the plan, Police Department
title: For $1.5 Billion, New York Plans a Much-Delayed Overhaul of 911

author: Charles V. Bagli and Ken Belson contributed reporting.
body: Ever since it was proposed, the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn has simultaneously been the borough's biggest, most controversial and least understood real estate development. Critics have long suggested that the project is a taxpayer-subsidized bonanza for the developer, the project's promised jobs and subsidized housing a kind of Trojan horse
title: Documents Show Risk In Big Project In Brooklyn

body: The Brooklyn Youth Chorus is regularly heard alongside prestigious ensembles in major works at Lincoln Center, Carnegie Hall and the Brooklyn Academy of Music. title: MUSIC REVIEW | BROOKLYN YOUTH CHORUS; Polished Young Choristers Evoking Eternal Mysteries

body: Eliot Spitzer's first legislative session was coming to a fractious close on Thursday night, as he and top lawmakers failed to reach agreement on a wide range of issues as they rushed to finish business for the summer. There appeared to be agreement on a small number of measures. One required suspects indicted on rape charges to take H.I.V. tests.
title: Spitzer and Legislature Sprint to Finish Line

title: CLASSICAL; The Listings

body: NO one who walks by Santo Matarazzo's neatly kept brownstone on Union Street in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, is likely to guess at the personalities gathered inside. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; The Union Street Hall of Fame

body: When the lights go out at the movies, the sound of crunching popcorn and the slurping of sodas can be bad enough. Not to mention that beefy guy at the end of the row who insists on narrating the onscreen action? Now, however, some
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Now Showing: The Pager And the Noisy Moviegoer

title: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; Brigit Pinnell, Lucas Falk

title: Brooklyn Waterfront Called Endangered Site

title: Judge Rejects Main Argument of Effort to Stop Atlantic Yards Project in Brooklyn

body: No canvas is too big for Richard Haas, a Manhattan-based artist whose trompe l'oeil murals embellish the urban landscape from New York to California. title: CURRENTS: ARCHITECTURE; McKim, Mead & White, Reinterpreted by Haas

body: In a move that has greater symbolic significance than mere real estate hopscotch, Galapagos Art Space, the pioneering bar and performing arts space that helped put Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on the cultural map, is moving a few neighborhoods down the East River, to Dumbo. Galapagos, which has played host to a broad array of New York's musicians,
title: Arts Space In Brooklyn To Get New Digs

body: GARDENING in New York City can require the determination of a weed pushing through a sidewalk. There are hardships of space, light, microclimate and wind, not to mention the pain of hauling supplies across town and, frequently, up several flights of stairs. Add to that the shortage of serious garden centers -- the kind with space for 50-pound bags
title: New York's Nurseries Try a Transplant

body: The letter arrived in Marilyn Oliva's mailbox yesterday from the Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz. It thanked her for her dedication to the community as a member of Community Board 6, but informed her that her services were no longer needed. Ms. Oliva was disappointed. She was also not alone. Though community board members' terms are
title: Project's Foes Shown Door In Brooklyn

body: As Rudolph W. Giuliani runs for president, his image as a chief executive who steered New York through the disaster of Sept. 11 has become a pillar of his campaign. But one former member of his inner circle keeps surfacing to revisit that history in ways that are unflattering to Mr. Giuliani: Jerome M. Hauer, New York City's first emergency
title: THE 2008 CAMPAIGN; Onetime Giuliani Insider Is Now a Critic From Outside

author: E-mail: haberman@nytimes.com
body: This just in: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has still not entered the presidential race. Thought you might want to know. There is, of course, absolutely nothing new in this. Mr. Bloomberg has said he is not running for president more times than Paris Hilton has been arrested. Now and then he has even suggested that the country may not be ready for a
title: NYC; Figuring The Next Field For the Mayor

author: Michael Weinreb is the author of ''The Kings of New York: A Year Among the Geeks, Oddballs, and Geniuses Who Make Up America's Top High School Chess Team,'' published in March by Gotham.
body: PATRICK O'NEIL, tall and broad-shouldered, towers over many of his classmates at the New York City College of Technology in Downtown Brooklyn, and at age 31 he is older than many of them. But there is also a less apparent gulf between Mr. O'Neil and his fellow students. ''I watch these people moving through their lives, and it's so odd,'' he said
title: Coming Home

body: Two New York City police officers have resigned after being accused of trying to rob the apartment of a suspected drug dealer in New Jersey, a law enforcement official said yesterday. Hector S. Alvarez and Miguel A. Castillo, both 28, were arrested on Friday by the police in Rutherford, N.J. They were each being held in $1 million bail on charges
title: Two Officers Tried to Rob Drug Suspect, Officials Say

body: City officials have devised what may be the ultimate test of demand for housing in New York: They are asking developers if they want to build apartments pressed up on the side of the Brooklyn House of Detention. For more than a year, officials at the Department of Correction have been considering whether to add stores and restaurants to the street
title: City Ponders Building Apartments Feet From a Jail

body: Transit officials said yesterday that they planned to resume regular maintenance and construction work on subway tracks and tunnels this morning, returning workers to the job after more than four days off for a safety review prompted by the deaths of two track workers struck by trains. The Transport Workers Union president, Roger Toussaint, said
title: After a Four-Day Safety Review, Subway Work Is Resuming

body: The new arts library designed by Enrique Norten that was supposed to rise like the prow of a glass ship near the Brooklyn Academy of Music now seems likely to sink, unrealized, into the pavement. All the same, planners say they have raised money for a new theater designed by Hugh Hardy for the academy and hope to break ground next year. Eight
title: Arts Library Planned In Brooklyn Hits a Snag

body: The curriculum drawn up to give New York City Transit workers an urgent refresher course in safety after two fatal on-the-job accidents last month draws a single, blunt conclusion for avoiding future disasters: ''No Short Cuts.'' The 60-page document that outlines the safety campaign makes the reason for the warning clear: A 2002 review of 81 fatal
title: In Subways, A Refresher On Safety

body: In response to the deaths of two track workers in accidents, transit officials yesterday suspended more than 20 maintenance projects for subway tracks, signals and tunnels for at least two more days. The decision was announced as workers attended the funeral of one transit worker, family members shared memories of another, and transit veterans
title: Work Stays On Hold After Deaths In Subway

As a historian of graphic design with a passion for architectural lettering, he sees A's, B's and C's in places that the untrained often overlook. title: STREETSCAPES/Architectural Lettering; A Man Who Minds His P's and Q's

body: About 350 people were temporarily ordered out of a homeless shelter in Brooklyn yesterday after a 200-foot-long parapet on the roof of an adjacent building that was about to be demolished to make way for the Atlantic Yards project collapsed, the authorities said. No shelter residents, pedestrians or workers on the roof were hurt when the parapet on
title: Parapet Falls From Building to Be Demolished for Atlantic Yards

body: THE lunch crowd coursed along Fulton Street Mall in Downtown Brooklyn on Tuesday afternoon, a river of people bundled up in trench coats and athletic jackets. title: STREET LEVEL -- Downtown Brooklyn; In Big Mac Country, Gilded Age Yearnings

Bloomberg is expected to propose tomorrow, faces daunting obstacles and even under the most optimistic conditions is likely to be years away, both supporters and opponents of the idea said. title: Drivers' Fee Would Face Uphill Battle

body: A State Supreme Court justice declined yesterday to issue a restraining order temporarily halting the demolition of nine vacant buildings to make way for the Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn. The restraining order had been requested by Develop Don't Destroy Brooklyn, which opposes the scale of the 22-acre project that is to encompass
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Atlantic Yards Can Proceed

body: A former State Supreme Court judge was convicted yesterday of accepting bribes to manipulate the outcome of divorce proceedings in a case that led to a broad political and judicial corruption inquiry in Brooklyn. The judge, Gerald P. Garson, 74, could face as many as 15 years in prison if he is sentenced consecutively on the three guilty verdicts,
title: Former Judge Is Convicted Of Bribery

body: The influx of thousands of new residents has reinvigorated this city's downtown in recent years, but most of the development has been clustered on its southern end, near the Staples Center, the sports and entertainment arena. title: Square Feet; In Los Angeles, a Gehry-Designed Awakening

title: LIVING IN/Downtown Brooklyn; Now Open for Living, as Well as Business

title: Clearing of Atlantic Yards' Site Proceeds as Legal Thicket Grows Denser

title: Marking Time, Making Do

title: Ex-Law Clerk Tells of Brooklyn Judge's Meetings and Gifts

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Robbery Suspect Arrested

title: LIVING IN/Red Hook, Brooklyn; Where Tugboats Chug and Ikea's Coming

body: The Downtown Brooklyn shopping plaza formerly known as the Albee Square Mall will soon undergo yet another incarnation: It will be razed, rebuilt at triple the size and topped with a high-rise with offices and a thousand apartments, its prospective new owners said yesterday. The mall is being sold to a partnership of developers for about $125
title: Deal Would Triple the Size of the Albee Square Mall in Brooklyn and Add a High-Rise

body: SHAWN LIPSCOMB has spent 13 of his 32 years in prison for two robberies; in one of them he shot and wounded the victim. He says the holdups were to support his cocaine addiction and live the life of ''the guys who had the cars, the females and the jewelry.'' Now, he says, he is determined to become a law-abiding, job-holding member of society.
title: OFFICE SPACE: HOME FRONT; From the Hope Program, A Path to a Fresh Start

body: Hakeem Jeffries, a state assemblyman who supports the $4 billion Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn, has denounced an important facet of it -- the name for the new arena for the Nets basketball team, which he called an affront to the black community. Another supporter, Roger L. Green, a former assemblyman, has said the Nets naming deal
title: Barclays Arena Deal Raises A Reputed Link to Slavery

body: SOMETIMES Bill Berloni feels like a phone psychic. ''People call about their adopted pets, and I've never seen their home,'' he said. ''One woman had a dog who was afraid of thunder, and neglected to mention that she lived next to an airport.'' For this reason, Mr. Berloni, an animal behaviorist and well-known Broadway animal trainer (he is
title: Nerves as Frayed as the Sofa? Call Your Own Dog Whisperer

body: Sally Mae Jenkins is full of stories. In a breathless rasp, she recalls traipsing through the woods of her native South Carolina, running from snakes and getting into dicey escapades with her 13 brothers and sisters. Then she talks of having a daughter at 17, only to lose her 25 years later. Each reverie is delivered in her thick-as-molasses
title: The Neediest Cases; A Warm Coat for a Woman With Endless Stories to Tell

body: For the fourth time in less than two years, Clarence Norman, the disgraced former head of the Brooklyn Democratic Party, sat in a courtroom yesterday, watching prospective jurors file in to sit in judgment of him. Much about the scene was familiar -- the figures at the prosecution table, the presiding judge and a set of charges that do not quite
title: Big Question Unanswered In Scandal

author: E-mail: geovec@nytimes.com
body: What would Walter O'Malley have thought about the $400 million naming rights for a sports arena atop the railroad station near Downtown Brooklyn, where he once feinted at building a ballpark? Maybe that kind of money, even at lower 1957 levels, would have kept O'Malley from stuffing the Dodgers into his satchel and lamming it westward. O'Malley was
title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; Naming Rights and Wrongs Across Time Zones

body: When the Nets were a goofball franchise, it was impossible to imagine their owners consorting with a global financial power like Barclays. But the Nets aren't laughable anymore, and yesterday, their principal owner, Bruce C. Ratner; some of his investors, like the rapper Jay-Z; and a few of their players were at the Brooklyn Museum to announce that
title: SPORTS BUSINESS; What's in a Name? $400 Million.

body: Setting a record price for the naming rights to an American indoor sports arena, the British bank Barclays has agreed to pay nearly $400 million over 20 years to put its name on the Nets' planned future home in Brooklyn. The arrangement could double the old record of $185 million for 20 years that Royal Philips Electronics paid to name Philips
title: PRO BASKETBALL; Record Price for Name on Nets' Arena

body: When Amanda M. Burden's stepfather, William S. Paley, built the vest-pocket park that bears his name on East 53rd Street, he saw to it that the four wide stone steps from the street, each only five inches high, stood as an invitation to enter. Those steps ''are just perfect,'' Ms. Burden recently recalled her mentor, the urban scholar William H.
title: Once at Cotillions, Now Reshaping the Cityscape

body: If anything else had gone wrong in December for the Nets, they might as well have parked the team bus in nearby Secaucus, N.J., waited for the draft lottery and made a packing list for Brooklyn. Jason Kidd's incendiary divorce papers became public record Tuesday, the biggest distraction yet for a team already suffering from fragile chemistry.
title: SPOTLIGHT: N.B.A.; With Brooklyn on Horizon, Nets' Brain Trust Considers All Options

body: Forest City Ratner Companies, the developer of the planned $4 billion Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, has insisted during the long public debate over the project that it will do anything to ensure that displaced residents will not be left out in the cold. But it has not done enough, say a group of tenants who filed the latest in a series of
title: Tenants Sue Agency Over Brooklyn Project

body: You can see them everywhere in the blocks near Cadman Plaza: lost tourists, brows furrowed over guidebooks, looking for that most elusive of landmarks, the Brooklyn Bridge. ''We had to ask four people,'' said Kelli Parsons, 21, a Londoner who on Wednesday morning had just found the entrance to the bridge's pedestrian footpath. ''We're useless,''
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; To Cross the Bridge, Job No. 1 Is to Get on It

body: Even at Atlantic Avenue and Court Street, a bustling corner of Brooklyn that is home to a freshly built luxury apartment building and a gleaming new Y.M.C.A., the structure on the southeast corner of the intersection is the shiniest thing in sight. It has tempered glass walls and a translucent roof, brushed-metal accents and an insouciant row of
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; Sleek They Are. But Will They Make the Cut?

author: Neal Hirschfeld is the author, with Kathy Burke, of ''Detective: The Inspirational Story of the Trailblazing Woman Cop Who Wouldn't Quit.''
body: ONE day this winter, on a pilgrimage that will be either blessedly cathartic or unbearably painful, a retired telecommunications worker and graphic artist named Dom Caruso will make his first visit to two gravesites at St. John's Cemetery in Middle Village, Queens. Mr. Caruso, a 70-year-old grandfather in fragile health, will begin by bowing his
title: A Father's Grief, A Father's Rage

body: City, state and federal agencies granted final approvals last month to a half-dozen wide-ranging projects in a political aligning of the stars that will promote New York City's most ambitious economic development agenda in decades. Approval or financing was given to a Second Avenue subway; an extension of the Flushing Line to the Far West Side; a
title: Wave of Development, Cleared for Takeoff
